proposals.reasoning: I want to avoid auto-repeating the Alice–Bob opener from last game and instead create an early comparison point. Putting myself with Alice gives the table a clear baseline: if this mission is clean, Bob’s alignment becomes more interesting when he joins later missions; if it fails, I’m directly accountable and we can immediately scrutinize the push I made away from Alice–Bob. This pairing maximizes early informational value while still using a generally trusted first-mission choice in Alice.

votes.comment: Team is reasonable and gives us good early info with a slight meta shake-up from last game; I’m fine starting here.
Charlie is pushing to replace me on a first mission most people were comfortable with; I’d rather start with the simpler Alice–Bob baseline than give extra control to the player arguing against it.
I know I’m good and Alice is a reasonable first-mission choice; this team gives strong early info without relying on last game’s meta.
I already said I prefer the more standard Alice–Bob opener; switching now to approve Alice–Charlie would be inconsistent and I don’t love creating an early potentially trusted pair I’m not on.
I preferred the simple Alice–Bob opener for a clean baseline; this shifts away from that without a strong enough reason for me to change course.

proposals.reasoning: I still want a straightforward, low-drama first mission anchored on Alice, but I’m adjusting slightly from Alice–Bob to include myself instead. This keeps the spirit of a simple baseline team while avoiding over-reliance on the same early pairings as previous games, and it gives the table a clean, easily comparable data point between Bob and Charlie for future missions based on how people react to this choice and the mission result.

votes.comment: I don’t love anchoring the baseline on a self-included team from the leader; I’d rather see Alice paired with someone other than the current leader first for a cleaner comparison later.

Diana shifted off her stated Alice–Bob preference to exclude me and Charlie; as confirmed good to myself, leaving me out lowers my confidence this is a clean team. I’d rather stick with the broadly supported Alice–Bob baseline.
Early missions are low info anyway; this still anchors on Alice, avoids repeating last game’s pairings, and gives us a clean read on Diana without stalling.
I proposed this as a clean baseline including myself with Alice; rejecting my own low-drama first mission would look inconsistent and suspicious.
Still a simple, Alice-anchored baseline and I don’t mind Diana stepping in instead of Bob for fresh comparison data between Bob and Charlie later.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d like a pretty “boring” team—people we’re comfortable scrutinizing later—so I’m happy to go, and between Bob and Charlie I’d give a slight early lean to Bob for the second spot. That still leaves plenty of room to adjust if the table has a stronger preference.
I’m fine with a simple Alice–Bob team to start; early info is better than overthinking the first mission. If anyone has a strong gut read against that, speak up now so we know where people stand.

I’d actually prefer an Alice–Charlie first mission so we’re not just defaulting to the same early pairing patterns as last game, and it gives us a clean comparison point with Bob for later. If there’s strong pushback on that, I’d want to hear why before we lock in Alice–Bob.

I slightly prefer Alice–Bob here just to avoid reading too much into meta from last game—clean, standard info to start is actually useful. If this passes, we’ll have a solid baseline and can compare Charlie’s push against it later.
I’m okay with the straightforward Alice–Bob start since it gives us a familiar baseline to read from, but if it comes back clean I’d really like to see Charlie on the next team for comparison.

proposals.reasoning: I want exactly one of the prior mission’s pair (Alice/Diana) plus two new players to widen the info net without auto-clearing anyone off a 2-person success. Keeping Alice from the first mission maintains some continuity, and adding Bob and myself fits both what multiple people have already said they’re comfortable with and the idea of not re-stacking Alice and Diana together again so early, where another success with the same core wouldn’t tell us much about the rest of the table.

votes.comment: I was initially fine with the Alice/Bob/Eve shape, but with both Diana and Eve quickly converging on this exact trio and Eve as leader putting herself on, I’d rather see a version that swaps in Charlie for Eve to avoid giving too much control to that cluster this early.
I’m on it, it matches the consensus structure (exactly one of Alice/Diana plus two new), and it should give strong info while still having a good chance to pass.

Team matches the broad consensus structure (exactly one of Alice/Diana plus two new players) and there’s no concrete reason to distrust any of them yet, so it’s a good info-gathering lineup even though I’m not on it.
Eve on the team gives evil influence and info, and the composition aligns with what most players said they were comfortable with, so rejecting would look suspicious.
Matches my stated preference of exactly one from Alice/Diana plus two new players; good info spread without over-clearing the first pair.

discussion.content: I’d rather not auto-clear anyone just off that 2‑person success, so for this one I like spreading it out with something like me plus two of Bob/Charlie/Eve instead of repeating the exact core from last time.

I’m fine not auto-clearing anyone, but I’d still like one of Alice/Diana on this team for continuity plus two new (I’d especially like to see myself on it, and I slightly prefer adding Eve over Charlie right now).

I’m with Alice on not over-clearing off a 2‑person success, so I’d like exactly one of Alice/Diana plus two of Bob/Eve/me, and I’d especially like to see myself on this one so we get more info on a new face.

Given the first mission was just a 2‑stack, I’d rather widen the net a bit, so something like Alice/Bob/Eve feels like a good info‑gathering team, and I’m okay sitting out here instead of just rerunning the same leader/core.

I like the idea of keeping exactly one of Alice/Diana from the first mission and adding two fresh faces, so Alice/Bob/me feels like a solid balance of continuity and new info. I’m a bit wary of putting both Alice and Diana back together this early when we don’t really learn much if it passes again.

proposals.reasoning: We need a low-overlap, information-rich team that still feels safe. Charlie hasn’t been on any mission yet, so including him gives us a fresh read. Between the players who’ve already been on teams, both Diana and I were on the successful Mission 1, but Diana is also the common suggestion with Charlie right now, which feels a bit too convenient given we just had a fail from a larger group. By going Alice + Charlie, we avoid fully repeating the Alice/Bob/Eve failing core while still keeping one proven-success player and adding one completely untested player, which should give a clearer signal about where the problem lies without leaning too hard into the Charlie + Diana consensus.

votes.comment: This avoids the full failed core, adds a fresh player in Charlie, and keeps the team small for a clearer info read on where the fail from last mission came from.
Either Alice or Eve must be evil from Mission 2, so a 2-person team including Alice is too risky; we should use a pair that avoids both Alice and Eve.
We can form a 2-person team (Charlie + Diana) that completely avoids the failed Mission 2 trio; Alice+Charlie still includes a member of that suspicious core and is less informative and less safe.
I still prefer the Charlie + Diana team: it avoids the full M2 failing core while not giving Alice a third straight appearance when she was on the failed mission.
I don’t love sending Alice again right after a fail she was on; I’d prefer a cleaner test like Charlie + Diana with less overlap from the failed mission.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 (Alice, Bob, Eve) had exactly one fail, and I know I’m good, so at least one of Alice or Eve must be evil. That means the two evils are drawn from {Alice, Eve} plus at most one of {Charlie, Diana}. Any team that excludes both Alice and Eve can contain at most one evil. By choosing myself plus Charlie, we both avoid the Alice/Eve cluster and ensure that if this mission succeeds, Charlie is very likely cleared as good (since I know my own role). If it fails, we get a very strong read that Charlie is evil. This gives a solid chance at a success while maximizing information gain for later missions.

votes.comment: Bob’s logic about avoiding the Alice/Eve cluster makes sense, and with no overlap from the failed mission besides Bob (who looks better than the others there), this is a strong, low-risk 2-person test.

From my perspective at least one of Alice/Eve must be evil from Mission 2, so only one of {Charlie, Diana} can be evil at most. Since I know I’m good, Bob+Charlie has at most one spy and is a reasonable, informative test.
Bob was on the failed Mission 2 while Diana wasn’t; from my perspective Charlie+Diana is a cleaner, lower-risk test than including Bob again here.
I still prefer a Charlie + Diana test; Bob was on the failed Mission 2, so I’m not comfortable with a 2-person team that leans so much on trusting him yet.

I’m still wary of how quickly Bob is centering himself in the ‘cleared’ logic after the failed M2; I’d rather see Charlie paired with Diana as previously discussed than give Bob this much trust right now.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 (Alice, Bob, Eve) had 1 fail, so at least one evil is among those three. A 2-person team of Charlie + Diana completely avoids the failing core except for Alice’s prior link to Diana on the successful Mission 1, which mildly clears Diana. This composition minimizes overlap with the suspicious group while including myself, whose alignment I know is good, and creates a clean information test: if this mission succeeds, it strongly suggests at least one of Alice/Bob/Eve is evil; if it fails, we immediately narrow suspicion onto Diana (from my perspective) and can recalibrate future teams accordingly.

votes.comment: This puts a lot of weight on Diana, who’s already been on the only successful mission and is now in every proposed 2-person team. I’d rather see a team that doesn’t hinge so much on one repeated player so we don’t risk a critical fail here.
Avoids the suspicious Alice/Bob/Eve trio from the failed Mission 2, gives a clean info test on Charlie/Diana, and we shouldn’t risk burning more proposals this round.

I know I’m good and Diana is mildly cleared from the successful Mission 1, while at least one of Alice/Bob/Eve must be evil from the Mission 2 fail. This 2-person team is our best low-overlap, high-info test right now.
This team avoids the failing Mission 2 core, fits the low-overlap logic I already argued for, and a 2-person team with me on it lets us get a strong info read from the result.
This gives a low-overlap info test and keeps me off the mission after the last fail, so I’m fine sending it.

discussion.content: With the last mission failing, I’d prefer we don’t send the exact same core again—maybe try a simple 2-person team like Alice/Bob or Alice/Charlie and see how that pans out.

Given the single fail on the Alice/Bob/Eve team and knowing I’m good, the spy has to be either Alice or Eve, so I’d rather see a 2-person team that avoids that overlap—something like Charlie + Diana or Charlie + me.
Given Mission 2’s fail, I’d like to avoid repeating that whole core for now—Charlie + Diana feels like the cleanest test, since we weren’t both on the failing team and Mission 1 with Diana succeeded.

Given the Mission 2 fail, I really don’t want to repeat too much of that Alice/Bob/Eve core, so a small Charlie + Diana team feels like the cleanest, lowest-overlap test. Mission 1 with Alice and me succeeding also makes me lean slightly more toward trusting Alice over Eve right now.

Given the M2 fail, I get why people are wary of repeating that core, so I’m fine with a smaller test like Charlie + Diana here. If that comes back clean, I’d lean toward revisiting Alice/Bob later with a bit more scrutiny on Alice, since she’s been on both teams so far.

proposals.reasoning: This team fits the compromise several people have been circling: it avoids reusing the exact failing pairs (Alice/Bob/Eve and Charlie/Diana) while not stacking both suspected buckets {Alice, Eve} and {Charlie, Diana} together. Including Alice and Bob preserves players that many have tentatively trusted, and having me instead of Charlie or Eve avoids the double-evil risk that comes from putting one player from each suspected bucket on the same small team.

votes.comment: I still feel safer avoiding both previously failing components entirely; I’d rather try me/Bob/Charlie than bring Diana from the Charlie/Diana fail back onto a critical 3-player mission.

Given the constraints from Missions 2 and 3, the only consistent evil pairs are {Alice,Charlie}, {Alice,Diana}, {Eve,Charlie}, or {Eve,Diana}. On team {Alice,Bob,Diana}, I know I’m good, but this team is bad in 3 of those 4 cases and good in only 1, so it’s overwhelmingly likely to contain at least one evil.
Mission 3 proves either Diana or I am evil; I know I’m good, so Diana is definitely evil and cannot be on a team I approve.
This matches the split-buckets logic I laid out earlier and avoids both known failing pairings, so I’m fine sending this.
My suspected pool includes at least one of Alice/Bob already; this team keeps me off while still fitting the compromise logic others support, so I’m fine sending it.

proposals.reasoning: This team avoids repeating either of the previously failing exact combinations (Alice/Bob/Eve and Charlie/Diana) while still using players who have been broadly trusted so far. It also follows the compromise structure discussed in table talk: Bob is on every suggested safe team, Alice is widely seen as relatively trustworthy, and Diana fits the split-buckets reasoning Bob and I described (one from {Alice, Eve} and one from {Charlie, Diana} rather than stacking both members of the same suspected pair). This should be acceptable to most players as a balanced, non-redundant lineup for a critical mission.

votes.comment: I’m still not comfortable putting Diana on this mission given her involvement in one of the small failed teams; I’d rather see a lineup that doesn’t include anyone from both prior fails together, like me/Bob/Charlie.

Given exactly one evil is in {Alice,Eve} and one in {Charlie,Diana}, any 3-player team with me must take one from each bucket. ABD fits that structure and matches the compromise I already argued for, so it’s as reasonable as any alternative and I’ll back it.
From my perspective I know I’m good, so the fail on the Charlie/Diana mission makes Diana extremely likely evil. I won’t approve any team including her on this critical mission.
I’m on this team and it fits the split-buckets logic we discussed, avoiding both prior failing combos while still including the broadly trusted core.
This matches the compromise structure I argued for earlier and avoids both previously failing exact combos, so I’m fine backing it here.

discussion.content: Given both fails came from small teams that each included Diana once and Eve once, I’d feel safest with a fresh combo like me, Bob, and Charlie this round rather than reusing those patterns.

From the mission results we pretty much know the two evils are one of {Alice, Eve} and one of {Charlie, Diana}, so putting both you and Charlie together is actually the riskiest combo. I’d rather see something like me/Alice/Diana or me/Eve/Charlie than a team that could easily contain both evils.

From my perspective the cleanest read is that Diana shouldn’t be on this mission at all, and the second evil is somewhere in {Alice, Bob, Eve}. Given that, I’m most comfortable with a team of me, Alice, and Bob this round.

I’m closer to Bob’s read here: if the evils are likely split between {Alice, Eve} and {Charlie, me}, then a team of Alice/Charlie/Bob can easily be double-evil, so I’d rather see something like Bob/Alice/me or Bob/Eve/Charlie than stack both “buckets” together.
Given the two fails came from (Alice/Bob/me) and (Charlie/Diana), I’m inclined to avoid repeating either exact pair and would lean toward a compromise like Bob/Alice/Diana this round.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was reasonably consistent in keeping suspicion off the confirmed-evil pair early, but I didn’t translate my knowledge into a clear good-leaning path for the team, especially around Missions 2 and 4. I could improve by signaling my trust in Bob and Charlie more strongly and earlier, and by steering teams away from Diana and Eve without looking like I had perfect information.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and felt genuinely conflicted after Mission 2, which read as authentically good but also made it harder for him to hard-push back on bad team comps. He tends to rely on mission results more than strong gut reads, which made him somewhat swayable late.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as quietly logical and not overly forceful, which made him seem more trustworthy but also easier to sideline from key decisions. He didn’t strongly leverage his good alignment to demand better teams, especially after Mission 3’s fail.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as leader on Mission 1 with a clean success, which gave her lingering credibility. She played assertively but not aggressively, and managed to stay on multiple teams without drawing enough heat even after suspicious results.
player_observations.Eve: Used Mission 2 effectively to create ambiguity, keeping suspicion spread out rather than focused on herself. She was comfortable taking leadership on Missions 2 and 4 and proposing mixed teams that always had at least one evil, while framing them as reasonable compromises.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Eve too easily after Mission 2, rationalizing the single fail in a way that let evil stay hidden for too long, and I didn’t push hard enough to scrutinize team compositions that repeatedly included the same suspicious players. I did reasonably well at staying calm and not overreacting to early fails, but I need to be more vocal about patterns across missions and more willing to challenge 'convenient' narratives that let certain players skate by.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played a very quiet, subtle Merlin game—she nudged teams in the right direction early (like Mission 1) without overtly hard-clearing or hard-accusing anyone, which made it tough to confidently read her as Merlin while still giving evil some resistance.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a straightforward, transparent style and seemed genuinely confused by the midgame logic knots, which made him read consistently good but also meant he didn’t exert strong influence over the critical team decisions.
player_observations.Diana: Diana balanced trust-building and targeted sabotage well; she got onto key teams without drawing much suspicion and her accusations felt calm and measured, which helped her pass as good long enough for evil to secure crucial mission fails.
player_observations.Eve: Eve leaned into being active and involved in team discussions, using that visibility to appear helpful while subtly steering lineups toward at least one evil player; her early willingness to sit with partial suspicion but not overdefend herself made her harder to pin down.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I pushed an early small team on Mission 3 that I felt good about and tried to keep table talk focused on concrete mission results. However, I clearly misread Diana and didn’t press hard enough on the implications of Mission 2’s fail, which let evil stay comfortably hidden and led me to propose a losing team.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough gentle nudges without over-claiming knowledge, which helped her avoid getting assassinated despite consistently being on key teams.
player_observations.Bob: Had a straightforward, earnest table presence and stuck to logical reasoning from mission results, but didn’t exert a lot of agenda-setting pressure, which made it easier for evil to sideline his reads.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very credible, low-friction evil game—accepted reasonable teams, avoided loud contradictions, and used the trust from Mission 1 to slip onto later critical missions and sabotage them.
player_observations.Eve: Positioned herself as a ‘reasonable skeptic’ after the Mission 2 fail, directing suspicion outward without being too defensive, and used leadership opportunities to construct teams that subtly protected fellow evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently believable as good by anchoring Mission 1 with a clean success and then only failing missions when it made strategic sense, which helped evil win without drawing too much suspicion directly onto me. I could improve by creating more proactive, vocal suspicion on non-Merlin good players earlier so that the endgame assassination would feel less pressured and more clearly directed.

player_observations.Alice: Very composed and willing to go on multiple teams, which made her look reliably good—but her presence on almost every key team was a subtle Merlin tell. She managed information carefully rather than loudly, suggesting she prefers quiet influence over overt table control.
player_observations.Bob: Played fairly straightforwardly good, going on multiple teams and not overasserting accusations, which made him a solid 'default trust' candidate. He seemed to follow the social consensus more than drive it, which can make him harder to read but also less dangerous as Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: His leadership on Mission 3 and willingness to take a small team with me suggested he was trying to be logical and risk-aware, which read very village-leaning. He didn’t strongly push any radical theories, so his playstyle comes off as methodical but not highly deceptive.
player_observations.Eve: Handled the evil role well by taking a pivotal leadership position twice and spreading the fails across different missions to avoid a clear pattern. Her team selections and participation created just enough ambiguity around where the evil players were, which gave me room to stay relatively under the radar as assassin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my sabotage on Missions 2 and 4 well, keeping suspicion diffuse and helping secure the evil win without drawing too much heat onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Diana and the mission compositions earlier, to better control where Merlin’s suspicions landed and to create more misdirection about who the true threats were.

player_observations.Alice: She played a cautious but influential Merlin, often placing herself on early teams and using subtle steering rather than aggressive accusations, which made her reads harder to detect as ‘Merlin-like’ in the moment.
player_observations.Bob: He tended to follow the emerging table consensus and was relatively quiet in pushing his own theories, making him appear generally trustworthy but also easier to mislead with confident claims from others.
player_observations.Charlie: He played straightforwardly and placed a lot of weight on mission results over social reads, which made him predictable in his team preferences and somewhat easier to manipulate by shaping which missions succeeded or failed.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she blended in well with the good team’s reasoning and didn’t over-defend suspicious players, which helped preserve her cover; at times she could have been even more assertive in seeding alternative suspects to pull attention away from the actual Merlin.
